text: Inhibition of protein phosphatases by okadaic acid induces AP1 in human T cells .

To examine the role of protein phosphatases in T cell activation , Jurkat cells were treated with okadaic acid , an inhibitor of type 1 and 2A phosphatases , and nuclear extracts were examined for the presence of AP1 as a measure of early T cell activation .
Okadaic acid was found to be a potent inducer of AP1 .

In contrast to phorbol esters such as phorbol myristate acetate ( PMA ) , the induction of AP1 by okadaic acid occurs predominantly by transcriptional activation of the jun and fos family of proto-oncogenes .
Surprisingly , while the addition of <extra_id_0> phytohemagglutinin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> further enhanced the induction of AP1 , the addition of PMA inhibited it .

Okadaic acid treatment was found to dramatically increase mRNA transcripts of the jun family of proto-oncogenes including <extra_id_0> c-jun <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> junD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> junB <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and to a lesser extent the fos family including <extra_id_0> c-fos <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> fra-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: By comparison , PMA is a very inefficient inducer of the jun gene family in Jurkat cells .
Similar to its effect on the induction of AP1 by okadaic acid , PMA inhibits the induction of <extra_id_0> c-jun <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA by okadaic acid .

text: The induction of AP1 by okadaic acid suggests that <extra_id_0> protein phosphatases 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> 2A <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( PP1 and PP2A ) may be involved in T cell activation as important negative regulators of the transcription factor AP1 .
